pages.text: $(mat)Welcome! I'll be your guide to the wonderful world of $(item)Salt Casted Materials$(mat).$(p)First, a little theory. As you know, $(l:intro/salt)Apprentice Salts$(/l) are capable of binding to many different kinds of Power, transforming when they do. If a single pile of Salt can do that, what about a whole block...?

$(mat)Simply throw a Salt Block into the Crucible with sufficient Power, and voila! A new material, never seen before!$(p)For this example, I used pure Mind, but any combination of Powers should work, even less common ones.

$(mat)Of course, infusing large amounts of Power into the Salt changes more than its appearance. Each $(item)Material$(mat) possesses some $(item)Properties$(mat) that affect how it behaves as a block. $(p)Some are simple -- break speed, light emission -- and some are... less conventional. I've documented each Property in this Journal.
$(mat)If you'd like to make a Material without any fancy properties, try $(item)White Wool$(mat) as a base! Wool absorbs the color from the provided Powers without taking on any unnatural effects.
$(mat)Also! You can throw $(item)a stack of Salt Blocks in at once$()$(mat) to create more then one Material Block -- the resulting Material is the same as if you'd just added one.

$(o)Well, you heard her! Go ahead: make yourself a Material and I'll show you more...$(p)If you'd like some advice, I would recommend starting with $(4)large amounts of single powers$(0) to get a feeling for what each one does.
